userreviews.userReview: The coming-of-age story line is remarkably well written. The only problem I had was that the POV seemed to be that of a female (probably because it was written by a female?) so I had a hard time staying in the main character's head. He would say and do things that seemed unlikely for an adolescent/teenage boy. But hey, I had two brothers and have a teenage son maybe I'm a little jaded. Can you say, "Where's my jeans?"

I enjoyed the colorful southern expressions in this book and found it surprisingly humorous. But I was confused by the mixed voice of the storyteller, it was supposedly a male voice but felt female. I had to keep reminding myself that Claybird was a boy, which took away from the storyline flow.
Very likeable main character. It seemed like a true story and I loved the way they talked to each other. The chapter about the first kiss, etc. was hilarious.
Fabulous. I love the Panhandle of Florida area and she captures it with this story from a young mans viewpoint. Poignant and funny!

I absolutely loved this book! The writing is fantastic and spot on when it comes to writing about the South (and the Florida South, at that). Because this story is told from the viewpoint of Clay during the age of 10-14 years old, the story is more heartbreaking in the sad parts and hilariously funny in the heartwarming parts. While observing the world through Clay's eyes, I could see everything he couldn't because he's simply too young to understand what's right in front of him. I loved his coming-of-age story and how he handled his grief and got over his learning disability with the help of his uncle Gabe. I loved reading about his battles with his siblings, his triumphs in school, and his complicated relationship with his mother, while navigating through adolescence and his grief over losing his father. The only reason I wouldn't give this story five stars is that it could use more dialogue in the areas where there are pages and pages of backstory. More dialogue could break that up a little and help with the flow of the story. Other than that, I'm actually surprised this author hasn't received more recognition. This is one of the best southern stories I've ever read.

Unintentionally, I’ve picked up a series of stories recently with pre-teen narrators – and this one, like the others, did not disappoint. I absolutely loved this story of family secrets and the coming-of-age of the main character, Claybird. His voice is so original, and despite the very serious nature of the storyline, he had me laughing out loud more times than I can count. What a wonderful mix of humor and deeply felt emotion.I read this book on my Kindle on the treadmill, and zipped right through it (sure made the workout less painful!). It is character-driven fiction at its best: an introduction to a southern Florida family struck by truly devastating loss that, in the end, results in so much personal growth. We meet Claybird; siblings Sim and Missy; parents Myra and Michael; and Uncle Gabe, Aunt Candace and Grannie (and a few others). We learn their southern traditions, can nearly taste their mouthwatering southern cooking – and we see the influence of religious traditions on moral decisions.This is ultimately a story of the power of forgiveness and the strength of love. Wonderful, wonderful southern storytelling!

This book is about a boy named Clayton loses his father, Michael because he was dead. Then all of a sudden Uncle Gabe comes back. Clayton didn't know him at all because he disappeared twenty years ago when he was going up north. Uncle Gabe was so hilarious that it makes Clayton hanging out with him. It makes his world turn upside down because he was spending time with him that he don't spend time with his family. I pick this book as a three stars for rating because this book sometimes make me don't understand what it is going on since it have a lot of southern accents. I think cowboys would understand this book better. Anyway, this book is all about family relationships that happens in everyday lives.

Another coming of age tale--another southern coming of age tale. This one told from the perspective of a preteen boy. Clayton "Claybird" Catts' finds the remedy for grief following the loss of his father in a hopeless history project--a project that has Claybird gathering family stories. He learns how his father and mother met, how his father persevered to overcome poverty and rise to millionaire status. But some family mysteries remain. Questions circle his brain and eventually some stories lead to clues to those family secrets. An explosive secret totally changes Claybird's life and begins a new round of questions...questions about his own identity.

Janis Owens writes very well. The plot was interesting but was as slow-moving as the river that lazily flowed past my grandmother's trailer when I was a child. The days then were endless with only brief moments of excitement. The life of Claybird Catts is much the same. Owens insight into southern family is spot-on, though, and her descriptions of family dynamics resonated with me to the point that I kept reading.

Slow start (for me) but very beautiful and deep ending It's the kind of book where you want to say thank you to the author. Thank you for recapturing these authentic feelings for a lost parent-- even if I had to "live" through Claybird's sort of dorky life to arrive there, it is genius for you to have created this experience. Thank you.

Is it possible I am biased because I know, or have met, the author? Not really. Janis is back, with a big-time New York publisher.Her third in this series tells the story from the point of view of Claybird, the child caught in the middle of the Myra, Gabriel, Michael triangle. Again, not a whiff of redundancy.

A nicely told story, with characters that continued to grow on me. "...but when all was said and done, my father had never left me at all; had never been any further gone than the closest mirror, if I'd have only thought to look."

Another summer reading book that I actually enjoyed reading for school. Owens has such a great writing style and the book was truly interesting. It was a quick read and was cause for great discussion.

Janis Owens is my new favorite author! This was the most enjoyable novel I've read in a long time - I appreciated her clever take on characters and culture, and wrapped it all up in messy, complicated, enduring unconditional love.

Thoroughly enjoyed the characters and development of this coming-of-age story set in the south...it's done in a unique way that charmed me from the beginning. This family will stay with me for a long time... they are very real.

Very good. Told from the POV of Clayton, a young boy growing up in Florida. Like anyone his age, he struggles with how his family is perceived as well as his current opinions on them himself. Such a good story.
Easy read and evokes emotion. I enjoyed the way it was written, though by the end of it I was a little confused as to what exactly the plot was..
Claybird is a hoot and just the right voice that I needed right now. i Southern novel that is easy to read and touches the heart. Just my style. :)
I absolutely love this book! I have read it three times and would read it again tomorrow if you asked me to!
Blah. Gave up after trying to get into this book twice. Loved her other book but not this one.
Great book. Read it. This young man grows up with problems most people would have a problem with but is able to over come and go on.
I finished it but could not get into it. I kept expecting something to happen but it never did. Disappointing.
somewhat reminds me of "perks of being a wallflower"its told by a naive and kind of slow boy.but i really loved the southern US atmosphere of the story.
Loved this book narrated by an adolescent boy. I would like to read the other two books she has written that have these same characters. The story is tender and sweet, yet heartbreaking too.

description: To be perfectly honest, the day my father died really wasn't the worst day of my life.When his beloved father, Michael, dies, Claybird Catts finds solace in the company of his close-knit family -- his mysterious and beautiful mother, Myra; his lovable, know-it-all sister, Missy; his newly grown-up brother, Simon; and his devoted grandmother, Cissie. Devastated by his loss, but secure in their love, Claybird feels as though life could almost go on as usual in their small, sleepy Southern hometown.Until Uncle Gabe comes back.A stranger to Claybird, Uncle Gabe is a brilliant academic who disappeared twenty years ago. Despite the deep mystery that surrounds him, Gabe's humor and intellect shine, and he quickly positions himself in the role of the Catts family's patriarch, filling the role of Claybird's dead father. Gabe and Claybird become coconspirators and best friends, until a slip of the tongue unveils the real history of their relationship, a heart-wrenching revelation that turns Claybird's world upside down.
title: The Schooling of Claybird Catts
